Instead, ITI says a U.S.-led coalition of countries can bring about more sustainable change by using the World Trade Organization to “tell China that failure to adhere to international norms and obligations will no longer be tolerated.” Garfield concludes: “The time to initiate negotiations is now.”

SILICON VALLEY MUST-READS

— YouTube’s new kids offering: “YouTube is planning to release a new version of its YouTube Kids app that will do away with algorithmically suggested videos and will only display videos from channels that a team of YouTube curators handpicks, a source familiar with YouTube’s plans told BuzzFeed News.”

— Chinese ride-sharing firm debuts in Mexico: “Chinese ride-hailing company Didi Chuxing has publicly launched in Mexico with a website advertising its service to drivers and passengers, setting the stage for a potentially expensive showdown with rival Uber,” Reuters reports.

Zuck hits Hill

With help from Margaret Harding McGill, Steven Overly and John Hendel

ZUCK HITS HILL — Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg is making a highly anticipated appearance on the Hill this week, amid revelations that Cambridge Analytica, a data firm with links to the Trump campaign, exploited data from as many as 87 million Facebook users.

— Consumer privacy groups still have questions about EU rule: Members of the Transatlantic Consumer Dialogue, which includes Consumer Watchdog and Public Knowledge, are urging Zuckerberg to describe, once and for all, what the company’s plans to implement updates for the EU’s General Data Protection Regulation look like on a global scale.
